title: Near-Earth object alert! 84-foot asteroid heads towards Earth. Will it collide or pass safely? Details her - The Economic Times
summary:
Near-Earth object alert! 84-foot asteroid heads towards Earth. Will it collide or pass safely? Details here

Publication Date: December 18, 2024
Source: The Feed

An 84-foot asteroid, 2024 XS3, is set to pass Earth safely at a distance of 2,080,000 miles. NASA confirms that there is no risk of a collision.

  • The asteroid is traveling at a speed of 23,423 miles per hour.
  • The closest approach will occur at 01:54 AM IST on December 18.
  • Asteroids like this are remnants from the early solar system, providing insights into Earth's history.
  • NASA employs advanced tracking systems to monitor near-Earth objects (NEOs).
“Monitoring these objects helps scientists prepare for potential future threats.”

This event highlights the importance of planetary observation in understanding and safeguarding against potential asteroid impacts.
newTitle: 84-Foot Asteroid 2024 XS3 Approaches Earth with No Collision Risk

SpaceX Dragon Cargo Capsule Returns to Earth After CRS-31 Mission

Publication Date: December 16, 2024 Source: Gadgets 360

SpaceX's Dragon cargo capsule successfully undocked from the ISS and is set to return to Earth carrying valuable research materials.

  • The capsule undocked on December 16 and is expected to splash down on December 17.
  • CRS-31's return cargo includes experimental specimens critical for microgravity research.
  • The Dragon capsule is the only cargo spacecraft that can safely return scientific materials to Earth.
  • The astronauts aboard the ISS have had their mission extended due to technical complications.
  • Nasa will rapidly retrieve the Dragon capsule post-splashdown to preserve integral experiments.
“The recovered cargo will be transported to NASA's Systems Processing Facility for further examination.”

title: NASA schedules return of Starliner crew in March - Daily Excelsior
A World-First Discovery - Twin Stars Trapped Orbiting Galactic Black Hole - NDTV
summary:
A World-First Discovery - Twin Stars Trapped Orbiting Galactic Black Hole

Publication Date: Today | Source: Nature Communications

A team of astronomers led by Florian Peißker from the University of Cologne has made a groundbreaking discovery of a binary star system, named D9, orbiting the supermassive black hole Sagittarius A* at the centre of our Milky Way galaxy. This discovery enhances our understanding of the extreme environment surrounding black holes and provides insight into the behavior of hypervelocity stars.

  • First detection of a binary star system near a supermassive black hole.
  • Binary star D9 orbits Sagittarius A* and is approximately 2.7 million years old.
  • Discovery helps explain why some stars move through space faster than others.
  • The data gathered could help unravel the nature of black holes.
“This discovery sheds light on the extreme environment at the centre of our Milky Way galaxy.”

This discovery not only adds to the understanding of black holes but also aids in solving cosmic mysteries such as the origin of hypervelocity stars.
newTitle: A World-First Discovery - Twin Stars Trapped Orbiting Galactic Black Hole

title: First Binary Star Detected Near Supermassive Black Hole - AZoQuantum
summary:
First Binary Star Detected Near a Supermassive Black Hole

Date: January 5, 2024 & Source: Nature Communications

An international team of researchers has identified a binary star system orbiting near Sagittarius A*, the supermassive black hole at the center of the Milky Way galaxy. This study provides valuable insight into how stars can survive in intense gravitational environments.

  • This is the first documented discovery of a stellar pair near a supermassive black hole.
  • The newly identified binary star D9 is about 2.7 million years old.
  • The D9 system is expected to merge into a single star within one million years due to the gravitational pull of Sagittarius A*.
  • This discovery challenges previous beliefs that new stars cannot form near supermassive black holes.
  • The identification of young stars suggests that stellar pairs can form even in extreme conditions.

“Black holes are not as destructive as we thought.” - Florian Peißker, Study Lead Author

The team used the European Southern Observatory’s Very Large Telescope to make this groundbreaking discovery. Upcoming advancements in telescope technology promise to further explore the nature of these young stellar systems.

“Our discovery lets us speculate about the presence of planets since these are often formed around young stars.” - Florian Peißker

This breakthrough lays the groundwork for future research into the surrounding environments of supermassive black holes and the potential existence of planets in these regions.
newTitle: First Binary Star Detected Near a Supermassive Black Hole

title: US faces risk of losing to China in second moon race - The Hindu
summary:
US Faces Risk of Losing to China in Second Moon Race

Published: December 18, 2024 05:02 pm IST

Source: The Conversation

As both the US and China prepare to return humans to the Moon, the US lunar program faces delays, while China is projected to land astronauts by 2030. This article explores the implications of a potential new Moon race and the challenges both nations face.

  • 12 Americans landed on the Moon between 1969 and 1972.
  • The US lunar program is behind schedule due to unprepared equipment.
  • China intends to land astronauts on the Moon by 2030, backed by a smooth-running space program.
  • Nasa's Artemis program aims to land humans on the Moon by 2026, with several milestones including Artemis I and II.
  • Critics suggest Artemis is overly complicated compared to China’s direct approach.
“Rushing back to the Moon could be costly, both financially and in the risk to human life.”

The upcoming Moon missions highlight competitive international space efforts and the importance of responsible exploration principles.
newTitle: US Faces Risk of Losing to China in Second Moon Race

title: How and when to watch 2024's final meteor shower - NewsBytes
summary:
How and when to watch 2024's final meteor shower

Date: December 21-22, 2024 Source: NewsBytes

The annual Ursid meteor shower will peak on December 21-22, offering a spectacular display for stargazers across India, coinciding with the winter solstice.

  • The Ursids will be most visible between 12:00am and 5:00am IST.
  • Peak viewing time is just before dawn on December 22.
  • Activity will be visible from December 17 to 26, with about 10 meteors per hour expected at peak.
  • Optimal viewing locations should have minimal light pollution.
  • The Ursids originate from debris of Comet 8P/Tuttle, with meteors appearing as Earth passes through this debris.
Darren Baskill, an astronomy lecturer at the University of Sussex explains, "As the Earth orbits around the solar system at 70,000 miles per hour, it ploughs through this dust, which we see briefly glow as it is swept up and burnt by the friction of our atmosphere."

To enhance the viewing experience, select a dark location, dress warmly, and allow your eyes to adjust to the darkness for 15-20 minutes.
newTitle: How and when to watch 2024's final meteor shower

InSight Lander studying ‘dust devils’ on Mars, spotted dead by NASA orbiter - The Times of India
summary:
InSight Lander studying ‘dust devils’ on Mars, spotted dead by NASA orbiter

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Times of India

The InSight lander has successfully studied dust devils on Mars before concluding its mission, as observed by NASA’s Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter. The end of its mission was marked by the inability to regain contact due to dust accumulation on its solar panels.

  • The InSight lander focused on Mars' internal structure and seismic activity.
  • NASA's MRO captured InSight's last images showing dust accumulation on its solar panels.
  • Despite attempts, communication has been lost, with efforts to reconnect set to end in 2024.
  • Dust devils play a significant role in Martian climate and surface dynamics.
“Even though we’re no longer hearing from InSight, it’s still teaching us about Mars.” - Ingrid Daubar, Brown University

The legacy of InSight’s findings on dust and Mars' climate will continue to inform future missions.
newTitle: InSight Lander's Journey Ends: Dust Devils on Mars Studied

What is a dark comet? A quick guide to the ‘new’ kids in the Solar System - The Hindu
summary:
What is a dark comet? A quick guide to the ‘new’ kids in the Solar System

Published - December 18, 2024 03:45 pm IST

This article discusses dark comets, mysterious celestial objects that are challenging our understanding of comets while recently more of these objects have been discovered.

  • NASA discovered ‘Oumuamua in 2017, the first confirmed interstellar object in our Solar System.
  • Dark comets do not exhibit the typical bright tails or nuclei associated with comets.
  • Researchers have identified two main categories of dark comets: smaller inner Solar System objects and larger outer Solar System objects.
  • Comets are typically icy bodies that reveal their characteristics as they near the Sun, unlike dark comets which appear similar to asteroids.
  • Dark comets' orbits are elongated, bringing them close to the Sun before returning to the far reaches of the Solar System.
  • Discovery of dark comets relies on reflected sunlight, with the Dark Energy Camera identifying new objects.
"In 2025, we’ll have a new mega camera in Chile ready to find them."

Dark comets may hold significant astronomical insights, and ongoing discovery efforts are expected to yield more information in the coming years.
newTitle: What is a dark comet? A quick guide to the ‘new’ kids in the Solar System

title: Primates often gave birth to twins 60M years ago: new research - The Hindu
NASA alert! Giant 84-foot asteroid 2024 XS3 to pass Earth today; will the asteroid collide? - The Times of India
summary:
NASA Alert: Giant 84-Foot Asteroid 2024 XS3 Passes Earth Safely

Date: December 18, 2024   Source: Times of India

Today, the Apollo NEO asteroid, 2024 XS3, will safely pass Earth at a distance of approximately 3.3 million kilometers. Discovered on December 3, 2024, it poses no collision risk.

  • The asteroid follows an elliptical orbit with a perihelion of 0.89 AU and an aphelion of 2.58 AU.
  • It is part of the Apollo asteroid group, taking approximately 833 days to complete one revolution around the Sun.
  • Scientists assure that after today, 2024 XS3 won't come closer than 45 million kilometers until 2027.
  • Asteroids like 2024 XS3 hold vital information about the solar system's formation.
  • NASA monitors Near-Earth Objects using advanced radar systems to track potential threats.
  • Ongoing efforts include missions aimed to detect and deflect hazardous asteroids.
"Asteroid 2024 XS3 serves as a reminder of the importance of asteroid monitoring and planetary defense."

In conclusion, while this encounter presents no threat, it highlights the ongoing need for monitoring of NEOs to ensure Earth's safety from future cosmic dangers.
newTitle: NASA Alert: Giant 84-Foot Asteroid 2024 XS3 Passes Earth Safely

summary:
Before Living on the Moon, Get Ready to Call a Submarine Your Home

Published On: Dec 18, 2024 | Source: India Today

The first crew of the SubSea project has completed a 60-day underwater expedition aimed at studying human adaptation to extreme environments, mimicking the conditions of space travel.

  • The SubSea project is a collaboration involving ESA, the Portuguese Space Agency, and the Portuguese Navy.
  • 25 volunteers lived in cramped quarters to simulate astronaut conditions.
  • The data collected will inform strategies for future human spaceflight missions.
“SubSea is an essential initiative to understand human resilience in extreme environments.” - ESA astronaut Andreas Mogensen

This project marks a significant advance in preparing for future explorations to the Moon and Mars, leveraging Portugal's unique research capabilities.

title: China astronauts script history with world’s longest spacewalk, break US record. Check details - The Economic Times
summary:
China astronauts script history with world’s longest spacewalk, break US record

Publication Date: Tuesday, [Insert Date]

Source: South China Morning Post

In a significant milestone, Chinese astronauts Cai Xuzhe and Song Lingdong have completed a nine-hour extravehicular activity, setting a new world record and surpassing a 22-year-old record held by the United States.

  • Chinese astronauts set a new record for the longest single spacewalk at nine hours.
  • The previous record of eight hours and 56 minutes was held by US astronauts James Voss and Susan Helms.
  • This achievement is part of China’s broader efforts to enhance its space program and compete on a global scale.
  • China's space program has recently seen significant advancements, including lunar missions and complex spacewalks.
“Both the astronauts were supported by crewmate Wang Haozhe, who remained inside the station.”

This accomplishment marks a significant step forward in China's ambitions in space exploration, showcasing its technological advancements and reinforcing its position in the international space race.

title: 5 stunning images of space discoveries captured by NASA James Webb Space Telescope - HT Tech
summary:
5 Stunning Images of Space Discoveries Captured by NASA's James Webb Space Telescope

Date: December 18, 2024

Source: HT TECH

This article highlights five remarkable discoveries made by NASA's James Webb Space Telescope, showcasing the incredible images captured that reveal the beauty and mystery of our universe.

  • The Webb image of quasar RX J1131-1231 located 6 billion light-years away.
  • Captures of the inner Orion Nebula and Trapezium Cluster, spanning 4 light years.
  • Near-infrared observations of Saturn providing insights into its orbital characteristics.
  • Discovery of supernovae SN 1987A located in the Large Magellanic Cloud at a distance of 168,000 light-years.
  • Galaxy Pair VV 191 imagery, showcasing the power of Webb and Hubble together.
“NASA James Webb Space Telescope is one such powerful observatory which has been a part of several unique discoveries.”

These stunning images not only demonstrate the capabilities of the James Webb Space Telescope but also highlight the ongoing exploration and discovery in the field of astronomy.

title: NASA’s InSight Mars lander: New HiRISE image reveals dusty resting place on the red planet - India TV News
summary:
NASA’s InSight Mars Lander Captured in New HiRISE Image Reveals Dusty Resting Place on the Red Planet

Publication Date: October 23, 2024 | Source: India TV News

The InSight Mars lander has been observed in a new image captured by the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, showing it covered in Martian dust, highlighting dust movement and wind patterns on Mars.

  • The InSight lander landed on Mars in November 2018 and studied the planet's seismic activity and internal structure.
  • The mission officially ended in December 2022 due to dust accumulation on its solar panels.
  • NASA's monitoring operations are expected to conclude by the end of 2024.
  • The recent HiRISE image helps researchers understand the Martian dust cycle and wind dynamics.
  • Dust accumulation has altered surface features, including the fading of geological marks made by InSight's landing thrusters.
  • The Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter continues to provide crucial data for current and future Mars missions.
“The latest image of InSight may mark the lander’s silent legacy, but it continues to contribute to our understanding of the dusty mysteries of Mars.” - NASA

This observation not only preserves the legacy of the InSight lander but also plays a critical role in preparing for future exploration missions on Mars.
newTitle: NASA’s InSight Mars Lander Captured in New HiRISE Image Reveals Dusty Resting Place on the Red Planet

Can humans have babies in space? Current mice sperm experiment may provide insights into human life beyon - The Times of India
summary:
Can humans have babies in space? Current mice sperm experiment may provide insights into human life beyond Earth

Publication Date: [Not provided]

Source: [Not provided]

As ambitions for interplanetary colonization grow, researchers are exploring whether humans can reproduce in space. A new experiment involving freeze-dried mouse sperm aims to uncover how space conditions affect reproduction.

Key Points:

  • Japanese researchers are studying mouse sperm stored on the ISS to analyze its viability after space exposure in 2025.
  • The findings could inform human reproduction capabilities in space environments.
  • Previous studies have focused on various species, revealing complexities in reproduction in microgravity.
  • Challenges include the effects of gravity on development and potential genetic damage from radiation.
  • Innovative IVF techniques are being developed for microgravity.

Notable Quotes:

“If reproduction works in space, it will reassure humanity. If it doesn’t, we need solutions.” - Professor Teruhiko Wakayama

Understanding reproduction in space is vital for future human settlements on the moon and Mars, impacting biodiversity preservation and societal survival in extraterrestrial environments.
newTitle: Can humans reproduce in space? Insights from current mouse sperm experiment
